questions.text: 50-year-old female patient presents with severe joint pain in her left knee and an inability to move the distal interphalangeal joints of her hand. She has a family history of psoriasis. Which of the following is the classical radiological finding in such cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pencil-in-cup deformity

The given clinical vignette mentions left knee involvement (asymmetrical joint involvement) with the inability to move the distal joint (arthritis of small joints in the finger), and a family history of psoriasis, suggesting the diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. Pencil-in-cup deformity with subluxation of the thumb is a classical radiological finding in psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: A 10-year-old child fell down the stairs. An X-ray was done. Identify the structure injured as marked in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tibial tuberosity

The given X-ray points towards the tibial tuberosity. This image shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral three-and-a-half fingers on the palmar side of the right hand, along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Examination reveals thenar atrophy. Which of the following structures, when affected, lead to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Carpal tunnel

The most likely nerve injured here is the median nerve, which occurs in Carpal tunnel syndrome. Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common entrapment mononeuropathy caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the fibro-osseous carpal tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum. Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the lateral 3 and a half digits.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy complains of fever and pain in the lower limb. There is a localised rise of temperature and tenderness in the region shown in the radiograph. ESR is raised. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ewing’s sarcoma

The clinical features and radiograph showing onion peel type of periosteal reaction point towards a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.

questions.text: In nerve injuries, if the outer sheath and nerve fiber are intact while the inner axons are damaged, what is it known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Axonotmesis

In nerve injuries, an intact outer sheath and nerve fiber with damaged inner axons is referred to as axonotmesis.

questions.text: A person with a gunshot wound of size 3 cm presents with a comminuted fracture of the tibia. On examination, the distal pulse could not be felt. Which grade does this belong to according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IIIC

The above-described wound belongs to grade IIIC according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification. Gustilo and Anderson’s classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures. An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete came to the orthopedic department with acute onset of pain in the lateral part of the foot while his routine practice. His radiograph of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jones fracture

The above radiograph shows a transverse fracture on the base of the 5th metatarsal at the metaphyseal- diaphyseal junction and the most likely diagnosis is Jones fracture. A strong abduction force to the forefoot causes a bending moment in the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction and results in Jones fracture. This type of injury occurs in a sudden change in direction by an athlete.

questions.text: X-ray spine of a patient with chronic back pain shows characteristic appearance of cod fish vertebrae. What is the investigation of choice to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

DEXA

Cod fish vertebrae in X-ray spine is suggestive of osteoporosis. The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is dual energy X-ray absorptiometry(DEXA). It measures the bone mineral density of an individual. These measurements are made at the lumbar spine or the hip. These measured values are compared using T scores. A T score ≤ -2.5 SD is suggestive of osteoporosis.

questions.text: An elderly lady diagnosed with osteoporosis was advised to start treatment with bisphosphonates. Since the patient refused to come to hospital frequently, she was prescribed a drug that is given on yearly basis. Which among the following is given to this lady?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Zoledronate

Zoledronate is bisphosphonate that is administered once a year. The drugs used in the treatment of osteoporosis which decrease bone resorption include bisphosphonates, denosumab, and SERMs (selective estrogen receptor modulators).

questions.text: A 4-year old girl is brought with high-grade fever, malaise, and severe pain over her left knee. Examination reveals tenderness over the medial aspect of the left knee joint. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Staphylococcus aureus

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute osteomyelitis. The most common organism causing osteomyelitis is Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female, a known case of osteoarthritis has come for her annual physical examination. You would expect to see Heberden’s nodes in the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Distal Interphalangeal Joint (DIP)

Heberden nodes are the knobbly appearance of DIP. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling. Bouchard’s nodes develop in PIP.

choices.text: Fracture shaft of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who had a road traffic accident was brought to the casualty. His right leg is shortened, internally rotated and adducted. The pulsation of the femoral artery is not felt. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior dislocation of hip

Diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is posterior dislocation of the hip. The shortening and attitude of the limb in flexion, adduction and internal rotation is characteristic of posterior dislocation of hip.

questions.text: The earliest site of infection in acute hematogenous osteomyelitis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Metaphysis

The earliest site of infection in acute hematogenous osteomyelitis is the metaphysis. It is also the most common site of infection.

choices.text: Posterior part of the vertebral body
Posterior part of the vertebral disc

questions.text: According to the Denis classification, which of the following is not included in the middle column of the spine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior part of the pedicles

According to the Denis three-column theory, the posterior part of the pedicles is included in the posterior column of the spine, not in the middle column.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the final stage of Pott’s paraplegia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Flaccid paralysis

Flaccid paralysis is seen in the final stage of Pott’s paraplegia. Pott’s paraplegia begins as a UMN lesion. So initially, the patient is asymptomatic but ankle clonus, increased deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar can be detected on clinical examination.

questions.text: Which test is being performed to detect fixed flexion deformity at hip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thomas test 

Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly affected by skeletal tuberculosis in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dorso-lumbar spine

Skeletal tuberculosis most commonly affects the dorso- lumbar (thoraco-lumbar) spine in adults (thoracic > lumbar). The cervical spine is most commonly affected in children.

questions.text: A six-year-old child presented with the given deformity. Identify the deformity.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cubitus valgus

The image shows the cubitus valgus deformity of left elbow most probably arising as a complication of lateral condyle fracture humerus which the patient had 3 years back.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilateral knee joint pain. The x-ray image of the joints is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Scurvy

The clinical presentation and the x-ray showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, and Frenkel’s line are suggestive of scurvy. Rickets can also present with bilateral knee pain, but normal bone mineral density, lack of radiographical signs such as cupping and fraying of the metaphysis and widening of the growth plate makes it an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is being examined using the shown test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Median nerve

Shown test is oschner's clasp test: When both the hands are clapsed together , index and middle fingers , fail to flex due to the loss of action of long finger flexors of the index and middle fingers which are supplied by the median nerve .
